, better known worldwide as the Mexican Caribbean.

Holbox Island, population 2,000, is north of Cancún, where the Caribbean Sea meets the Gulf of Mexico. It is part of the 154,000 square kilometer Yum Balamecological reserve. It is known in particular for its whale sharks.

You get to Isla Holbox by taking a ferry from Chiquilá. It's run by the company Nine Hermanos, costs MXN80 and runs daily at 06:00, 08:00, 10:00, 11:00, 12:00, 13:00, 14:00, 16:00, 17:00, 19:00, and 21:30. On weekends it also runs at 15:00 and 18:00. It takes about 25-30 minutes. With two or more people you can charter a fisher's boat for the same price.

To Chiquilá by car: from Cancún (follow signs on the road), take Hwy 180 (called Merida Libre) or Avenida José López Portillo, direction to Merida. Keep to the right when the road separates. At El Ideal, turn right to Kantunilkin, and you will arrive in Chiquilá, where the road ends.

There are a few busses daily from Cancún to Chiquilá. From Mérida you can take a night bus at 23:30, arriving in Chiquilá at 05:30, passing Valladolid around 02:30. If you prefer traveling during the day, you can take a bus from Mérida or Valladolid to Tizimín and change there to a bus to Chiquilá.

The island of Holbox is very small and there are no paved roads, only sandy paths. There are very few cars on the island and most people get around by walking, bicycle, or golf cart. You've got a good chance to see flamingos and lots of other birds if you walk the beach west or east away from town.

value: content=Tours depart daily from late May through September, with peak season in July and August. Most tours leave at 09:00, returning around 14:00.  Requires a one-hour bouncy boat ride, but passes dolphins, flamingos, and maybe turtles and manta rays. Ceviche lunch included, as well as snorkeling at a well-used reef with potentially cloudy visibility. Visitors are generally allowed three times in the water with the sharks, no touching is allowed. Standard price is MXN1,200, although cheaper deals may be found; note that anyone charging less than the standard rate may not be a completely legitimate business and thus may not be following all regulations designed to protect the whale sharks.

Credit cards are not widely accepted. There are three ATMs on the island, but they're not very reliable and it is best to take along enough cash for your stay.

value: content=Very local place, specialized in antojitos (panuchos, sopes, tacos, chalupes, all MXN10 each).
directions=At the very end of the fifth street from the pier.
price=Tents, USD8+; hammocks, USD10+; beds, USD12+; private cabañas, USD45+

content=Unique, fresh and cozy, the campground is 80 m from the main beach and offers to backpackers the possibility to sleep on hammocks or beds in small wooden cabañas protected with mosquito nets, as well as within tents on the soft sand of the garden. Includes all basic comforts such as hot water, electricity, and ventilators. Additional to communal kitchen, laundry, BBQ grill and toilets, the camping provides also a fully equipped house for families and small groups who desire a bit more privacy.

content=It offers island-themed rooms and suites, all of which have balcony/deck, Internet connection, and private toilet and bath. Massage service, restaurant and bar, and recreational activities (whale shark viewing, sunbathing, snorkeling, and windsurfing).

content=Nice palapa huts with fan and hammock, sand floors, shared bath (MXN300), air-con rooms (MXN400). Dorm beds (MXN100). Shared kitchen. Free Wi-Fi. Owners Italian, multi-lingual, and can help arrange tours and other activities.
directions=3 blocks from the pier and 40 m from the beach
content=Brand new hostel with dorm rooms, private rooms, kitchen, Wi-Fi, book exchange, cinema, bike rental, tours, laundry.

The ferry from Holbox to Chiquilá runs at 5:00, 7:00, 9:00, 10:00, 11:00, 12:00, 13:00, 15:00, 16:00, 18:00 and 20:00, and on weekends also at 14:00 and 17:00.

Busses from Chiquila:

value: To Cancún: 05:30, 07:30, 13:30. The trip takes 3.5 hours and costs about MXN83.
To Merida: 05:30. The trip takes almost 7 hours and costs MXN150.
To Tizimín: 05:30, 07:30, 13:30, 16:30. The trip takes 3 hours and costs about MXN70.

Tizimín has two bus stations where you'll find busses to several destinations, including Valladolid. In Valladolid you can catch plenty of buses to Mérida, so you can consider spending some hours here and move on in the evening.

The buses are run by Autobuses del Noreste en Yucatan, are second-class and stop at a lot of places during the journey.
